responses.content:

1. Either P or Q (In this case, 'Either Fido is inside or Fido is in the garden')
2. Not Q (In this case, 'Fido is not in the garden')
3. Therefore, P (In this case, 'Fido is inside')

In this form of argument, if the first premise (P or Q) is true, and the second premise (Not Q) is true, then the conclusion (P) must be true. This is because if Q is false, then the only way for the first premise to be true is if P is true. Therefore, the argument is logically valid.
